description: From Middle English aureole, from Old French aureole, from Medieval Latin aureola (corona) ("golden (crown)").

entries.meaning: A circle of light or halo around the head of a deity or a saint.
examples: She feels, with all our furniture,
Room yet for something more secure
To guide our poor forgotten souls  […]

entries.meaning: (by extension) Any luminous or colored ring that encircles something.
examples: It was a lean Jewish face, with a great fuzzy aureole of white hair and a small goatee beard  […]

entries.meaning: (geology) A ring around an igneous intrusion.
examples: Cleavage and folds are imprinted are overprinted by the contact metamorphic aureole, indicating that they belong to a pre-intrustive episode of rock deformation and accompanying regional deformation.
